It is bordered byRomaniato the north,SerbiaandRepublic of MacedoniaMacedoniato the west,GreeceandTurkeyto the south, and theBlack Seato the east. With a territory ofconvert110994km2uk, Bulgaria is Europe'sList of European countries by area16th-largest country.

Organisedprehistoriccultures began developing on Bulgarian lands during theNeolithicperiod. Its ancient history saw the presence of theThraciansand later theAchaemenid EmpirePersians,Joseph Roisman,Ian Worthington."A companion to Ancient Macedonia"John Wiley & Sons, 2011. ISBN 144435163X pp 135-138, pp 343-345Ancient GreeceGreeksandRoman EmpireRomans. The emergence of a unified Bulgarian state dates back to the establishment of theFirst Bulgarian Empirein 681 AD, which dominated most of theBalkansand functioned as a cultural hub forSlavsduring theMiddle Ages. With the downfall of theSecond Bulgarian Empirein 1396, its territories came underOttoman EmpireOttomanrule for nearly five centuries. TheRusso-Turkish War (187778)led to the formation of the Third Bulgarian State. The following years saw several conflicts with its neighbours, which prompted Bulgaria to align with Germany in both world wars. In 1946 it became a single-partyPeople's Republic of Bulgariasocialist stateas part of the Soviet-ledEastern Bloc. InRevolutions of 1989December 1989the rulingBulgarian Communist PartyCommunist PartyallowedMulti-party systemmulti-partyelections, which subsequently led to Bulgaria's transition into ademocracyand a market-based economy.

Bulgaria's population of 7.4 million people is predominantly urbanised and mainly concentrated in the administrative centres of itsProvinces of Bulgaria28 provinces. Most commercial and cultural activities are centred on the capital and largest city,Sofia. The strongest sectors of the economy are heavy industry, power engineering, and agriculture, all of which rely on local natural resources.

The country's current political structure dates to the adoption of a democratic constitution in 1991. Bulgaria is aUnitary stateunitaryparliamentary republic with a high degree of political, administrative, and economic centralisation. It is a member of theEuropean Union,NATO, and theCouncil of Europe; a founding state of theOrganization for Security and Co-operation in Europe(OSCE); and has taken a seat at theUnited Nations Security CouncilUN Security Councilthree times.

article.paragraph: mainSecond Bulgarian EmpireAfter his conquest of Bulgaria,Basil IIprevented revolts and discontent by retaining the rule of the local nobility and by relieving the newly conquered lands of the obligation to pay taxes in gold, allowing them to be paid in kind instead.cite bookHistory of the Byzantine StateOstrogorskyGeorg1969Rutgers University Press311He also allowed theBulgarian Orthodox ChurchBulgarian Patriarchateto retain itsautocephalyautocephalous statusand all itsdioceses, but reduced it to anarchbishopric of Ohridarchbishopric.cite bookThe ByzantinesCameronAveril2006Blackwell Publishing978-1-4051-9833-2170After his death Byzantine domestic policies changed and a series of unsuccessful rebellions broke out,Bulgarian uprising against the Byzantine Empire (1040-1041)the largestbeing led byPeter Delyan. In 1185Asen dynastynoblesIvan Asen IandPeter IV of BulgariaPeter IVorganised aUprising of Asen and Petermajor uprisingwhich resulted in the re-establishment of the Bulgarian state. Ivan Asen and Peter laid the foundations of the Second Bulgarian Empire withVeliko TarnovoTarnovoas a capital.cite webhttp://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/84090/Bulgaria/42727/The-second-Bulgarian-empire?anchorBulgaria – Second Bulgarian EmpireEncyclopædia Britannica31 March 2012

article.paragraph: Kaloyan, the third of the Asen monarchs, extended his dominion toBelgradeandOhrid. He acknowledged the spiritual supremacy ofthe Popeand received a royal crown from apapal legate.cite webhttp://en.wikisource.org/wiki/1911_Encyclopædia_Britannica/Bulgaria/HistoryHistory of BulgariaEncyclopædia Britannica 1911[[James David Bourchier]]19119 December 2011The empire reached its zenith underIvan Asen II(12181241), when commerce and culture flourished.The strong economic and religious influence of Tarnovo made it a "Third Rome", unlike the already declining Constantinople.cite bookESSENTIAL HISTORY OF BULGARIA IN SEVEN PAGESIvanovLyubomir2007Bulgarian Academy of Sciences4http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Essential_History_of_Bulgaria_in_Seven_Pages20 December 2011The capital Tarnovo became a political, economic, cultural and religious centre seen as 'the Third Rome' in contrast to Constantinople's decline after the Byzantine heartland in Asia Minor was lost to the Turks during the late 11th century.

The country's military and economic might declined after the Asen dynasty ended in 1257, facing internal conflicts, constant Byzantine and Hungarian attacks andMongol invasion of EuropeMongol domination.cite webhttp://www.shsu.edu/~his_ncp/Mongolia.htmlThe Golden HordeLibrary of Congress Mongolia country study4 December 2011The Mongols maintained sovereignty over eastern Russia from 1240 to 1480, and they controlled the upper Volga area, the territories of the former Volga Bulghar state, Siberia, the northern Caucasus, '''Bulgaria (for a time)''', the Crimea, and KhwarizmBy the end of the 14th century, factional divisions betweenboyarsthe feudal landlordsand the spread of Bogomilism had caused the Second Bulgarian Empire to split into three tsardomsTsardom of VidinVidin,Second Bulgarian Empire#Ivan Alexander and fall of BulgariaTarnovoandDespotate of DobrujaKarvunaand several semi-independent principalities that fought each other, along with Byzantines, Hungarians, Serbs,Venetian RepublicVenetiansandGenoese RepublicGenoese. By the late 14th century theOttoman Turkshad started their conquest of Bulgaria and had taken most towns and fortresses south of the Balkan mountains.

article.paragraph: Tarnovo was captured by the Ottomans after a three-month siege in 1393. After theBattle of Nicopolisin 1396 brought about the fall of the Vidin Tsardom, the Ottomans conquered all Bulgarian lands south of the Danube. The nobility was eliminated and the peasantry wasSerfdomenserfedto Ottoman masters,cite webhttp://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/84090/Bulgaria/42728/Ottoman-ruleBulgaria – Ottoman ruleEncyclopædia Britannica21 December 2011With the capture of a rump Bulgarian kingdom centred at Bdin (Vidin) in 1396, the last remnant of Bulgarian independence disappeared. ... The Bulgarian nobility was destroyed—its members either perished, fled, or accepted Islam and Turkicization—and the peasantry was enserfed to Turkish masters.with much of the educated clergy fleeing to other countries.cite bookJirečekK. Thus, Bulgarians, like other Christians, were subjected to heavy taxes and a small portion of the Bulgarian populace experienced partial or completeIslamisation,cite bookMinkovAntonConversion to Islam in the Balkans: Kisve Bahası - Petitions and Ottoman Social Life, 1670–1730BRILL200419390-04-13576-6https://books.google.com/books?idand their culture was suppressed.Ottoman authorities established the RumMillet (Ottoman Empire)Millet, a religious administrative community which governed all Orthodox Christians regardless of their ethnicity.cite bookDetrezRaymondEurope and the Historical Legacies in the BalkansPeter Lang Publishers20083690-5201-374-8https://books.google.com/books?idMost of the local population gradually lost its distinct national consciousness, identifying as Christians.cite bookFishmanJoshua A."Handbook of Language and Ethnic Identity," Disciplinary and Regional PerspectivesOxford University Press20102760-19-537492-4https://books.google.com/books?idThere were almost no remnants of a Bulgarian ethnic identity; the population defined itself as Christians, according to the Ottoman system of millets, that is, communities of religious beliefs. article.paragraph: Several Bulgarian revolts erupted throughout the nearly five centuries of Ottoman rule, most notably theHabsburg MonarchyHabsburg-backedcite webhttp://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/84090/Bulgaria/42730/Ottoman-administrationBulgaria – Ottoman administrationEncyclopædia Britannica20 October 2012Tarnovo uprisingsFirst Tarnovo Uprisingin 1598andSecond Tarnovo Uprisingin 1686, theChiprovtsi Uprisingin 1688 andKarposh's Rebellionin 1689.In the 18th century, theAge of EnlightenmentEnlightenmentin Western Europe provided influence for the initiation of a movement known as theNational awakening of Bulgaria.It restored national consciousness and became a key factor in the liberation struggle, resulting in the 1876April Uprising. Up to 30,000 Bulgarians were killed as Ottoman authorities put down the rebellion. The massacres prompted theGreat Powers#HistoryGreat Powersto take action.SfnThe Final Move to IndependenceThey convened theConstantinople Conferencein 1876, but their decisions were rejected by the Ottomans. This allowed theRussian Empireto seek a solution by force without risking military confrontation with other Great Powers, as had happened in theCrimean War.SfnThe Final Move to IndependenceIn 1877Russo-Turkish War, 18771878Russia declared waron the Ottoman Empire and defeated its forces with the help ofOpalchentsiBulgarian volunteers.
article.heading: Third Bulgarian state
article.paragraph: mainHistory of Bulgaria (1878–1946)People's Republic of BulgariaHistory of Bulgaria since 1989File:The defeat of Shipka Peak, Bulgarian War of Independence.JPGthumbleftalt=The Defence of the Eagle's Nest, painting by Alexey Popov from 1893, depicting the Defence of Shipka PassThe Russian and BulgarianBattle of Shipka Passdefence of Shipka Passwas crucial for the independence of Bulgaria.cite newsReminiscence from Days of Liberation*http://novinite.com/view_news.php?idNovinite3 March 201120 December 2011TheTreaty of San Stefanowas signed on 3 March 1878 by Russia and the Ottoman Empire, and included a provision to set up an autonomous Bulgarian principality roughly on the territories of the Second Bulgarian Empire.SfnSan Stefano, Berlin and Independencecite bookBlamiresCyprianWorld Fascism: A historical encyclopediaABC-CLIO20061-57607-941-4107https://books.google.com/?id20 December 2011The "Greater Bulgaria" re-established in March 1878 on the lines of the medieval Bulgarian empire after liberation from Turkish rule did not last long.The otherGreat Powers#HistoryGreat Powersimmediately rejected the treaty out of fear that such a large country in the Balkans might threaten their interests. It was superseded by the subsequentTreaty of Berlin, 1878Treaty of Berlin, signed on 13 July, provided for a much smaller state comprisingMoesiaand the region ofSofia, leaving large populations of Bulgarians outside the new country.SfnSan Stefano, Berlin and Independencecite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/1061402.stmBBC News20 December 2011Timeline: Bulgaria – A chronology of key events6 May 2010This played a significant role in forming Bulgaria's militaristic approach to foreign affairs during the first half of the 20th century.SfnHistorical Setting

The Bulgarian principality wonSerbo-Bulgarian Wara war against Serbiaand incorporated the semi-autonomous Ottoman territory ofEastern Rumeliain 1885, proclaiming itself an independent state on 5 October 1908.cite bookBulgariaCramptonR.J.2007Oxford University Press978-0-19-954158-4174In the years following independence, Bulgaria increasingly militarised and was often referred to as "the BalkanPrussia".cite bookDillonEmile JosephThe Inside Story of the Peace Conferencehttp://www.mirrorservice.org/sites/ftp.ibiblio.org/pub/docs/books/gutenberg/1/4/4/7/14477/14477-h/14477-h.htm20 December 2011February 1920Harper978-3-8424-7594-6XVThe territorial changes which the Prussia of the Balkans was condemned to undergo are neither very considerable nor unjust.cite bookPinonReneL'Europe et la Jeune Turquie: les aspects nouveaux de la question d'Orient1913Perrin et cie978-1-144-41381-9https://books.google.com/?idOn a dit souvent de la Bulgarie qu'elle est la Prusse des BalkansFrench20 December 2011File:Bulgarian soldiers with wire cutters WWI (contrasted).jpgthumbalt=Photograph of Bulgarian soldiers cutting enemy barbed wire during World War IWorld War I: Bulgarian soldiers cutting barbed wire laid by theEntente Powersand preparing to advance.Between 1912 and 1918, Bulgaria became involved in three consecutive conflictstwoBalkan WarsandWorld War I. After a disastrous defeat in theSecond Balkan War, Bulgaria again found itself fighting on the losing side as a result of its alliance with theCentral Powersin World War I. Despite fielding more than a quarter of its population in a 1,200,000-strong armycite bookTuckerSpencer CWoodLauraThe European Powers in the First World War: An EncyclopediaTaylor & Francis19961730-8153-0399-8https://books.google.com/books?idcite webhttp://www.cepr.org/meets/wkcn/1/1699/papers/Broadberry_Klein.pdfAggregate and Per Capita GDP in Europe, 1870–2000: Continental, Regional and National Data with Changing BoundariesBroadberryStephenKleinAlexander8 February 2008Department of Economics at the University of Warwick, Coventry1824 May 2012and achieving several decisive victories atBattle of Doiran (1917)DoiranandBattle of DobrichDobrich, the country capitulated in 1918. The war resulted in significant territorial losses, and a total of 87,500 soldiers killed.cite webWWI Casualty and Death Tableshttp://www.pbs.org/greatwar/resources/casdeath_pop.htmlPBS9 July 2013More than 253,000 refugeesimmigratedto Bulgaria from 1912 to 1929 due to the effects of these wars,cite journalhttp://www.ceeol.com/aspx/getdocument.aspx?logidExternal Migration in BulgariaMintchevVesselinSouth-East Europe Review3/998 May 2013October 1999124placing additional strain on the already ruined national economy.cite bookRethinking Violence: States and Non-State Actors in ConflictChenowethErica2010Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs978-0-262-01420-5129https://books.google.com/books?idBulgaria, for example, had a net surplus of refugees and was faced with the daunting task of absorbing thousands of Bulgarian refugees from Greece over a relatively short period. While international loans from the Red Cross and other organizations helped to defray the substantial costs of accommodating surplus populations, it placed a strenuous financial burden on states that were still recovering from the war an experiencing economic downturn as well as political upheaval.

The political unrest resulting from these losses led to the establishment of a royalauthoritarianismauthoritarian dictatorshipby tsarBoris III of BulgariaBoris III(19181943). Bulgaria entered World War II in 1941 as a member ofAxis Powersthe Axisbut declined to participate inOperation Barbarossaand saved its Jewish population from deportation toNazi concentration campsconcentration camps.SfnBulgaria in World War II: The Passive AllianceThe sudden death of Boris III in the summer of 1943 pushed the country into political turmoil as the war turned against Germany and the Communist guerrilla movement gained momentum. The government ofBogdan Filovsubsequently failed to achieve peace with the Allies. article.paragraph: Bulgaria is aparliamentary democracyin which the most powerful executive position is that of prime minister.SfnLibrary of Congress200616The political system has three brancheslegislative, executive and judicial, withuniversal suffrageforcitizensat least 18 years old. TheConstitution of Bulgariaprovides also possibilities of direct democracy.en iconNavigator to Direct Democracy"Overview of direct democratic instruments in Bulgaria"Elections are supervised by an independent Central Election Commission that includes members from all major political parties. Parties must register with the commission prior to participating in a national election.SfnLibrary of Congress200617Normally, the prime minister-elect is the leader of the party receiving the most votes in parliamentary elections, although this is not always the case.SfnLibrary of Congress200616

Political parties gather in theNational Assembly (Bulgaria)National Assembly, which consists of 240 deputies elected to four-year terms by direct popular vote. The National Assembly has the power to enact laws, approve the budget, schedule presidential elections, select and dismiss thePrime Minister of BulgariaPrime Ministerand other ministers, declare war, deploy troops abroad, and ratify international treaties and agreements. ThePresident of Bulgariapresidentserves as thehead of stateandcommander-in-chiefof the armed forces, and has the authority to return a bill for further debate, although the parliament can override thepresidential vetoby a simple majority vote of all members of parliament.SfnLibrary of Congress200616

Meat consumption is lower than the European average, given a notable preference for a large variety of salads.Rakiais a traditional fruitbrandywhich was consumed in Bulgaria as early as the 14th century.cite newsArcheological Find Proves Rakia Is Bulgarian Inventionhttp://novinite.com/view_news.php?id10 October 2011Novinite20 December 2011Bulgarian wineis known for itsTraminer,Muscat (grape)MuskatandMavrudtypes, of which up to 200,000 tonnes are produced annually.cite webhttp://www.investor.bg/news/article/60913/5.htmlThe Russians bought 81 mln. litres of Bulgarian wineInvestor Group BG15 April 2010cite newsThe Bulgarian Table, from Sudjuk to Shopskahttp://novinite.com/view_news.php?id4 August 2011Novinite20 December 2011Until 1989, Bulgaria was the world's second-largest wine exporter.cite newsBulgaria Bounces Backhttp://www.novinite.com/view_news.php?id7 February 2012Novinite7 February 2012

article.paragraph: Bulgaria performs well in sports such aswrestling,Olympic weightliftingweight-lifting,boxing, gymnastics, volleyball, football and tennis.cite webhttp://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/84090/Bulgaria/42718/Sport-and-recreationBulgaria- Sport and recreation2011Encyclopædia Britannica20 December 2011In international sports competition, Bulgarians have excelled in tennis, wrestling, boxing, and gymnastics, but the country's greatest repute may be in weight-lifting. ... Fans of football (soccer), the most popular sport in Bulgaria, were buoyed by the success of the national team in the 1994 World Cup, when it advanced to the semi-final match under the leadership of forward Hristo Stoichkov. The premier league in Bulgaria has 16 teams, of which four play in Sofia: CSKA, Levski, Slavia, and Lokomotiv.The country fields one of the leading men's volleyball teams, ranked sixth in the world according to the 2013FIVBrankings.cite webhttp://www.fivb.org/en/volleyball/VB_Ranking_M_2013-10.aspFIVB official rankings as per October 7, 2013International Volleyball Federation (FIVB)7 October 201326 October 2013Association footballFootballis by far the most popular sport.Some famous players areAS MonacoforwardDimitar BerbatovandHristo Stoichkov, winner of the Golden Boot and theGolden Ball (FIFA)Golden Balland the most successful Bulgarian player of all time.cite webhttp://www.epfl-europeanleagues.com/fao/hristo_stoichkov.htmHristo Stoichkov – Bulgarian League AmbassadorProfessional Football Against Hunger4 December 2011Prominent domestic clubs includePFC CSKA Sofiacite webhttp://bgclubs.eu/ranking/pointsRankings of A GroupBgClubs20 December 2011cite webIngo Faulhaberhttp://www.iffhs.de/?a413f0e03790c443e0f40390b41be8b01905fdcdc3bfcdc0aec70aeedb883ccb05ff1dBest club of 20th century ranking at the official site of the International Federation of Football History and StatisticsIffhs.de20 December 2011andPFC Levski Sofia.
